qas.question: When was Malta introduced to neoclassical architecture?
What was the ruler at the time of neoclassical introduction?
In what year did the St Paul's Pro-Cathedral get built?
What was introduced in Malta in the late 1800s?
What became unpopular in Malta following the establishment of British rule?
Who was the ruler of Malta following the neoclassical period?

context: <b4_0>Neoclassical architecture<b4_0/> was introduced in Malta in the <a0_0>late 18th century<a0_0/>, during the final years of <a1_0><b6_0>Hospitaller<b6_0/><a1_0/> rule. Early examples include the Bibliotheca (1786), the De Rohan Arch (1798) and the Hompesch Gate (1801). However, <b5_0>neoclassical architecture<b5_0/> only became popular in Malta following the establishment of <b7_0>British<b7_0/> rule in the early 19th century. In 1814, a neoclassical portico decorated with the British coat of arms was added to the Main Guard building so as to serve as a symbol of British Malta. Other 19th century neoclassical buildings include RNH Bighi (<a2_0>1832<a2_0/>), St Paul's Pro-Cathedral (<a3_0>1844<a3_0/>), the Rotunda of Mosta (1860) and the now destroyed Royal Opera House (1866).
